text: I am with a company called hello robot and we'll talk a bit about the robot we've developed and also a little bit
about some of the prior work I've done uh first off Stanford Alum very happy to
be back uh it's been an institution uh dear to my heart that's me back when I
was 18 and first got to campus and I think that was not long after the Loma Prieta earthquake so even a lot of the
campus was closed back then um and for the talk you know I went back
through my archives and tried to find some of the old projects I've worked on and also tried to think about you know a
Common Thread about some of the work that I've done over the years and so you can see various humanoids there's a
tensegrity robot there's a biped the underwater robot with with Asama uh
collaborative robot arms for manufacturing work with Google analysis of robots and I think the Common Thread
is really around robots that work around people and what that means for these machines to interact with people and so
I want to talk a little bit about that and I've sort of coined it as being sort of humanizing robot design uh term I
just made up for this talk but so why why is that important and for hello robot in particular
you know we have this this caregiving crisis that's about to happen across the world right this is really uh our we
don't have enough people to care for the older adults uh it really is a crisis and if you think about someone who's
home alone unable to get out of bed easily and doing something as simple as getting up and getting a glass of water
getting some pills it can take a huge effort and and this is going to be commonplace this type of problem we
commonplace across the world very soon and uh so it really is a place where
robots can help and I think we we have an ability to and that we should help uh
but for today what I want to talk about is what does it mean to do sort of human-centric design for for robots
uh and one key aspect for me is really participatory design which means to put
the stakeholders in the center of the design process and really talk to them and involve them so that we know that
what we create is going to meet their needs and I I hope to highlight some work that shows why that's so important
um and so to put the human experience at the center of the design means to really think about what it means for them to have this machine in their in their home
and what's that experience for them is it enjoyable does it bring value to them is it frustrating and really think that
through carefully rather than building the technology without an eye towards that so today I'll talk about kind of
five areas which I think are really relevant to this one is safety particularly if we're working with older
vulnerable populations one is Simplicity and it's very hard to get to Simplicity but it really matters
in terms of product experience the experience of the robot affordability Which is less commonly
researched it's not part of academic life as much but very important if you want to have impact you want to get
these robots out in the world and scale capability for us at hello robot you
know if it's useful it's exciting if it's capable it's exciting we want these robots to do meaningful work
and meaningful also means that for the person it actually enriches their life it makes their life better that brings
value in a very important way so I'll highlight how these five areas have kind
of found a thread through my work and with hello robot uh let me just start with a quick
introduction to the company we are based in the Bay Area Up in Martinez California near Berkeley
uh I'll play this is a about a two minute video it's a our product launch video
that's my son Levi who's sitting in the back there he just waved
um [Music]
oh [Music]

build it in Martinez California uh sell it to research Labs internationally it
really is a platform for Innovation so it's open source lots of great sort of software apis and we're really
encouraging people to explore the future of mobile manipulation with this platform and we've been seeing great Traction in
the community in terms of adoption people building machine learning models on top of it adding new hardware Etc
and uh successful launch we've won some Design Awards with it a great growing
Community we have them all over the world at this point and just starting to see great Publications come out with it
as well in that hello robot we really do take seriously the sense of purpose with with
the robots I really believe that these types of machines can improve life for everyone and we also recognize this as a
massive undertaking and that we should embark on this with the whole Community to try to build this future together
so um let's talk a bit about safety which I think is uh it's a very difficult topic and
there's lots of Notions of what safety is there's this ISO standard for it which uh is uh really pertinent to a
robot-like stretch but in the end safety is about um you know controlling interaction forces often it's about managing pinch
points Crush points lacerations toppling and when we're talking about robots with
vulnerable populations we really have to take it seriously and it's not not a trivial topic I've done some work over
the years in safety uh notably a lot of work with serious elastic actuators and all different types of forms and
variants the main thing about this type of actuator if you're not familiar it puts the spring and series with the
gearbox what that does is it decouples the effect of inertia of the motor and that gearbox winding up and when it hits
someone it lessens that impact effectively so that's a really nice attributes it has some disadvantages of
around complexity uh the fourth bandwidth position accuracy so there are
trade-offs there but they have found their way into commercial applications um you know at my company Mecca we took
the the work that I did at MIT built humanoids like this one dreamer at UT Austin uh and then you can see a video
here of one of the humanoids that we built back in the early 2000s and that robot everything is serious elastic
actuator including the hands the fingers it really was fun to interact with very compliant interactive it felt very
natural since my company Mecca's found its way into some commercial robots the Baxter
robot by rethink apptronic has a humanoid using that technology now
there's actually an exoskeleton for physical rehab that's using it so really interesting technology with stretch we
didn't take that path and hopefully it will illuminate a bit why so first off
for safety you know one thing I've learned over the years is really you have to take a systems approach you
can't just solve the component just the actuator you have to think about the whole thing so with stretch the thought
about how do we lower the overall Mass to the manipulator how do we make it so we're not making these massive uh
actuators to fight gravity so most of the actuation stretches down on the base and it really makes out that uh
manipulator to be very lightweight low inertia makes it safer it's also because it's a telescoping joint makes it very
intuitive people understand the motion as it's happening you know a seven-off arm it can do these complex planning
planned motions and people just don't know how to interact with that and becomes unsafe so really with stress we
really took safety as a starting point from the full systems View and came up with a very different type of design
uh of course a robot like stretch has toppling hazards because it is lightweight but it's got a small
footprint and so some static analysis on the Tipping stability that we did uh
because it's simple kinematics we get simple close forms expressions of that and what we find is we can get
reasonable forces really the biggest tip tipping Hazard is in in uh pooling can
pull itself over supporting a payload it does fairly well but you know we can get
modest pulling forces at full height and full extension and what that means is that we can actually do reasonable tasks
in households we can't do everything we can't open a refrigerator door up high but we can open it down low for example
uh and still with despite all the thought we put into safety there are real hazards with a machine like this uh
toppling is is one of them falling down staircases one so you really have to still address this this issue in in home
settings um and also once you get into autonomous motion it comes very hard to say anything uh definitively about what what
can happen and so you know we are still working on how to think about safety more long term for this product
um move on to simplicity now this is a robot built at MIT it's my PhD work a robot named Domo you can see
there all the stuff that I had in it and dozens of actuators a dozen computers
um probably five or six different cameras super complex uh
it was a lot of fun to build it was also you know very easy to stack up that type of complexity you know we just bolted
one thing to the next and um so so complexity is much easier to
get to than Simplicity often so there's a cool machine but you know I've learned from that to avoid this type of
complexity um and one bit of work that came out of MIT from Rodney Brooks's lab that I
really took inspiration from still do is this uh this is Herbert it was um
had 8-bit microprocessors he was able to navigate uh the the offices of the Mita
lab drive around find Coke cans pick them up and take them back to a location and it did all that with a very limited
computation and what they did is they really matched the robot to the environment they thought carefully about
where do you find Coke cans how do you recognize those those features with simple sensors and tune that whole
system to that one task and remarkable what I could do back then and this
notion of affordances comes out of some some writing by Don Norman which I really find inspirational and so with
stretch we took that same approach and we thought about you know you know what is a home really
you know do we need to have a general purpose humanoid in there how can we design a robot that matches that home
and so homes have lots of flat surfaces floors countertops table tops
and we thought well a lot of a lot of what matters happens around flat surfaces build a system that is really well designed for that and maybe we can
simplify the overall design problem so the nice thing that comes from that
things like surface wiping which is a common task that people would like to have done in a home becomes much simpler
it's almost trivial to do in this case so this is autonomous wiping
and you can see a very simple plan and so what could be a very hard problem
becomes a very simple problem likewise overall just planning and
manipulation for the robot becomes simpler one thing we put a lot of thought into is where to put the camera
it might seem like a fairly simple thing but we really wanted to give the robot a good workspace a view of its hand while
it's manipulating a view down while it was navigating and the the key thing is you know our environments are built we
look at them from above often and too often you see robots of the camera down low looking up and that Viewpoint
doesn't do a give it the right perspective you need to work in a human environment and so with this robot
planning manipulation becomes a lot simpler also because of the Cartesian kinematics in the placement of that
sensor uh also you know we really wanted to be
something that felt more like an appliance you know some of these the robots that are home robots weigh 400
pounds you need a truck with a lift gate to move it this I really wanted it to feel more like a rolling suitcase you
just pick it up and roll it around and you saw in the video my son was able to at age eight to just wheel the robot
around so that was a very important design constraint for us simple to ship seems very prosaic but the fact that we
can put it in a cardboard box and ship it by UPS just changes the business that we have
albeit UPS is terrible with robots we've had some terrible experiences there
simple to field so you can put in the back of a car take it to a home experiment you know the fact that you
can throw it I put in back my Prius all the time it's just it changes what the robot is and how you interact with it
um so that's uh Simplicity talk about affordability again the lesson I've gathered in getting to low cost is it
really is a systems problem this pie chart is sort of the the cost of of stretch as you can see it's not
one one pie wedge is is like the dominant cost you really have to solve all these different pie wedges
um and also there's all these hidden costs right so the shipping cost the warranty cost all the packaging for the
robot it just adds up and so if you're building a low-cost product you can't
just focus on you know the actuator or the sensor you have to think about the whole thing
uh some some of the first work I did in low-cost with with Professor kakoski
here at Stanford SRI this is a low-cost hand that was done for DARPA really cool
technology packed in there so I had Twisted string actuators so a little piece of string you'd wind up like an
airplane rubber band it would pull on the tendon each finger had a electrostatic clutch so with one motor
you could do three degrees of freedom in each finger tactile skin capacitive encoded on the
on the fingers so super cool hand unfortunately it didn't make it past this prototype never got commercialized
but we we did learn a lot about kind of developing low-cost Technologies
um but here's another take on a low-cost hand so this is the stretch hand and what we did is we let Amazon
crowdsource the the design by you know we look at all the assistive Grabbers on
Amazon you know looked at the highest rated one you know this had thousands of reviews
said well this one must work pretty well and so we took that added a dynamixel Servo except for eighty dollars in
quantity one we have a we have a gripper and it works remarkably well by the way so
a a later project I had was a company called Redwood robotics we're doing collaborative robot arms you can see
here it's Force sensitive uh and this was it was a full low-cost arm sheet
metal and belts timing belts uh strain gauges from China that were five dollars each uh and it worked really well we got
good Precision out of it good Force sensitivity uh a little bit ugly in this prototype
but um you know we're really going down the path of can we get to a very low-cost collaborative arm for
manufacturing and you know around the time we were about to start commercializing we got bought by Google
so that turned into a project at Google that I that I led which is these robots here that's that's
our Redwood arm it's an arm Farm they're doing machine learning uh reinforcement learning with the arm loading to grasp
objects um that project unfortunately got got shut down so we never got to the light
of day with that but but I ended up spinning up a project that became Everyday Robots which is a mobile
manipulation project and you know one lesson there was that well you can make a low-cost arm it's
not the same as a low-cost uh system low-cost mobile manipulator and the arm is just one component of that box so
you know with the arm we're very focused on the transmission and getting that cost down getting rid of harmonic drives
for example but really the whole robot has you know so many sensors and compute
and the total cost that those gearboxes are small in comparison
um so really you know again systems design is what with stretch gave us a significant cost reduction so far lower
degrees of freedom because of the kinematic Arrangement and you can see you know we're down here we saw it for about twenty thousand dollars with a
good profit which means our bomb cost is a very low because we really took the systems approach seriously uh and in
comparison you know most other robots 5x 10x more expensive
talk a bit about capability we really want it stretch to be useful for people in homes we did a lot of testing a lot
of just eyes on tell operation of the robot in homes cleaning toilets wiping surfaces picking up toys playing games
with kids just to verify that the robot could actually do it even with tele operation and this is in comparison to
other manipulation platforms that are super interesting technology but just to
me aren't credible to be in the home anytime in the future uh and so you know when we start at
stretch we're inspired by the PR2 which is a fantastic platform but you know it's very large uh it's
about 500 pounds 400 000 and it just wasn't going to be a credible robot for the home the thing is you can't just
shrink that robot right it doesn't won't be a capable robot and so uh rather than
shrinking it we had to kind of rethink what it meant for it to have our home robot and what we came up with we can
call robot cubism right you take the intent of a human but you're not building a human exactly so it's sort of
a deconstructed robot we put it back together with the systems approach in mind
and some of the characteristics are first off it has the reach of roughly of a 50 percentile uh male so very good arm
reach and by the way it scales very well so if we made a bigger version because of that telescoping arm for every you know inch
you add in the base width you get about three and a half inches in reach so a bigger version could have very very long reach
designed to reach on countertops where people put a lot of things we care about manipulating
if you reach the floor and has a great work space on the floor the PR2 could reach the floor barely could barely
reach over its base but really we wanted we knew we wanted to pick up stuff that people drop right that was one of the
design considerations uh hip width so very important in a home to be able to navigate cluttered spaces
too often you see videos of homes that are very wide open floor plans and no no
clutter most homes are very tight passages very a lot of clutter so we tried to hit the size of a Roomba uh in
terms of the base size and finally we put some thought into making sure we could actually do useful
tasks around people who are seated in wheelchairs so being able to manipulate around their face maybe it's a feeding task and so these were the design
constraints that we went went in with and what we came up with you can see is very down on the left
corner here in terms of the width so it is a Roomba size base and the weight so it's about 25 kilo
kilograms so it really is a diff in a different part of the design space because it is a very different type of
type of robot and as I mentioned we did lots of
testing in home by tell operations just to verify that it could work we also did a fair amount of autonomous
work to verify that it could be used in the research Community to do things like machine learning and so we found it to
be very capable in this regard uh and just to highlight one bit of work that came out of the community
um because we really do believe that the community will be carrying this this work forward and applying the
latest techniques particularly machine learning this is from Carnegie Mellon uh it's a visual imitation learning so
someone demonstrates to the robot what to do the robot can then learn from that and they've done about 20 different home

real value that can be created and often people really find it to be an enjoyable

now one thing that we did which I think is really uh compelling and you don't see it often
is we have an occupational therapist on staff and excuse me

uh Henry by the way he has can use a computer so he has control of his thumb for Mouse
click and eye gaze to move a cursor and that's his primary way of interacting
and one thing that Henry likes to remind everyone of is what he calls the caregiver principle
which is basically to say if the caregiver doesn't believe in the technology won't adopt it then it's
never going to get used right and they have to find it easy it has to be almost trivial for them to set up and so that's
really the gateway to this technology adoption so in his case it's his wife Jane and so really the robot has to make
